thread.title: Two more companies announce Cuba cruises
thread.title_full: Two more companies announce Cuba cruises

author: Gene Sloan , USA TODAY
title: Two more companies announce Cuba cruises
text:
Tourists from the United States are seen in old American cars in Havana, on April 6, 2015. (Photo: Yamil Lage, AFP/Getty Images)
Tags Cuba 155 CONNECT 14 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Add package tour giant Globus and small-ship line Haimark to the list of companies selling Cuba cruises.
Colorado-based Globus on Wednesday announced it would begin nine-night cruise tours to Cuba out of Miami in January that use a ship operated by Greece-based Celestyal Cruises.
Just hours later, Chicago-based Haimark said it would begin offering nine-night cruises to Cuba out of Miami starting in February on its 210-passenger Saint Laurent.
Both of the offerings will be structured as "people-to-people" exchanges that are allowed under the USA's five-decade-old embargo of Cuba. General leisure travel from the USA to Cuba including traditional cruises still is banned.
The announcements come just a week after cruise giant Carnival Corp. announced plans to begin people-to-people tours to Cuba via ship in May with the company's new social impact-focused brand fathom .
USA TODAY
Cruise giant Carnival Corp. to launch sailings to Cuba
The new Globus cruises will feature port stops in Havana, Maria La Gorda, Pinar del Río, Cienfuegos and Santiago de Cuba, with fares starting at $3,249 per person. The trips will take place on the 960-passenger Celestyal Crystal , which tourgoers will board in Havana after flying as a group from Miami.
The Haimark trips will feature stops in Havana, Maria La Gorda, Cienfuegos, Trinidad, Santiago de Cuba, Parque Nacional Alejandro de Humboldt and Holguin, with fares starting at $4,599 per person.
Globus holds a license from the U.S. Treasury to operate trips to Cuba under the U.S. embargo. Haimark says it plans to operate its trips in partnership with United Caribbean Lines, one of several ferry operations that received a license from the U.S. Treasury in May to sail to Cuba. Haimark says the trips are contingent on government approvals.
Globus and Haimark are entering an increasingly crowded field of companies offering people-to-people tours to Cuba. Just last month, package tour giant Apple Vacations announced it would add such trips this fall, joining a growing number of land-based tour companies offering Cuba tours.
For a deck-by-deck tour of the Celestyal Crystal, formerly known as the Louis Cristal, click through the carousel below.
The 25,000 gross ton, 960-guest Cristal is operated by the Celestyal Cruises division of Cyprus-based Louis Cruise Line. Over the years, this interesting vessel has transitioned from hard-working Baltic ferry to full time cruise ship. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Cristal was built in 1980 as the ferry Viking Saga for Viking Line’s Helsinki to Stockholm service. (Photo: Viking Line) Fullscreen In 1986, the Viking Saga was transferred to newly formed Sally Cruises and renamed Sally Albatross for Baltic cruising from Helsinki. In 1988, it was rebuilt with an enlarged superstructure. (Photo: Rami Wirrankoski) Fullscreen After suffering a major shipyard fire, the Sally Albatross was completely rebuilt in 1992, taking on the streamlined appearance it has today. Only the engines and portions of the original hull remain. (Photo: Rami Wirrankoski) Fullscreen In 1994 and early 1995, the ship was taken to Genoa and further rebuilt for full time cruising and subsequently chartered to U.S.-based Norwegian Cruise Line. As their Leeward, it was deployed on short cruises from Miami to the Bahamas. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Leeward had a double occupancy capacity of 952 guests and was a popular member of the NCL fleet before the advent of its new generation of Freestyle ships with multiple dining and entertainment venues. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen In 2000, the Leeward was switched to a new cruising base in Asia as the Superstar Taurus for NCL’s parent company Star Cruises. (Photo: Johan Van Delden) Fullscreen In 2002, the ship returned to Baltic waters as the Silja Opera. (Photo: Kalle Id) Fullscreen In 2007, Silja Opera was sold to Louis Cruises and renamed Cristal. Since that time, it has been engaged mainly in Mediterranean cruise service. The name was modified to Louis Cristal for several years but will revert to Cristal for the 2015 cruise season. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Cristal has nine passenger decks, beginning at the top with Deck 10, the farthest forward portion of which is an observation platform. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Deck 10 continues on either side of the radio mast with sheltered sunning platforms. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The midships portion of Deck 10 features an open sunning area that overlooks the pool. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The al fresco Helios Bar is just forward of the pool on Deck 9. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The pool on midships Deck 9 can be covered by a sliding steel and glass dome in inclement weather (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen On either side of the pool, there are tables and chairs. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Cristal has terraced afterdecks with open and shaded seating. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen On Deck 5, there is a promenade that fully encircles the ship. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The aft portion of Deck 5 is lined in teak and home to the popular, al fresco Caruso Terrace Bar as well as a large whirlpool tub. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Stars Disco is a 360-degree observation lounge and nightclub at the base of the ship’s funnel on aft Deck 10. On the port side, there is a dance floor and DJ booth. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The starboard side of the Stars Disco is terraced with booth seating on its inner side. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The aft portion of Stars features a long bar and a great view over the ship’s stern. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The double deck Metropolitan Show Lounge is located on forward Decks 9 and 8. The balcony is accessed via a staircase in the lounge and seats 94. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The lower portion of the Metropolitan Show Lounge begins a full deck of public spaces on Deck 8. It seats 344 guests and features a dance floor and large stage to accommodate production shows, guest singers, lecturers and even cooking demonstrations (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Sana Spa is located on forward Deck 9 and offers a wide range of massage treatments and skin therapies. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Several rooms provide unique treatments, including a hydro therapy bath. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen This treatment room is equipped with a thalassotherapy tub and a private hamam or Turkish bath. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Men and women have their own dressing and steam areas in the Sana Spa. This is the men’s sauna (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen A compact but well-equipped gym is on the starboard side of Deck 9. It features 3 treadmills, an elliptical, 5 climbers and a small arsenal of free weights. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Beauty Salon is located between the Sana Spa and pool area on Deck 9, offering hair styling and coloring as well as manicures and pedicures. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Located directly aft of the showroom, the forward portion of the Casino features black jack, roulette, poker and slots. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen More slots share space with the Casino Bar, which is located on the starboard side of Deck 8. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The 131-seat Rendez Vous Lounge is aft of the showroom on the port side of Deck 8. It is used for a language lessons and other scheduled events by day and features live music at night. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The aft portion of the Rendez Vous Lounge has comfortable seating with a nice view of the sea through large picture windows. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen A trio of small rooms called the Symposium is located on the starboard side of Deck 8, beginning with the 12-seat Library. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Accommodating up to 20 guests, the Kid’s Room is next to the Library on starboard Deck 8. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Conference Room on starboard Deck 8 can seat up to 35 guests. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Two stairtowers and four lifts provide vertical access aboard the Cristal. The midships stairtower features an eight deck tall, backlit acrylic mural. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The midships to aft portion of Deck 5 is also dedicated to public spaces, beginning with the photo gallery. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen A large duty free shop is located along the midships Deck 5 passage. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Eight computer terminals form a small internet center in the reception area on Deck 5. The Cristal also has wifi (accessed for a small fee) in most public spaces and key deck areas. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Reception area is near the midships staircase on Deck 5. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Shore Excursions desk is directly across from the Reception area on Deck 5. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Two dining venues occupy either side of Deck 9. On the port side, there is the casual 112-seat Traviata Buffet. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen On the starboard side of Deck 9, there is the 76-seat Rigoletto, which transforms into the Alberta Steakhouse at night. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen At breakfast time, there is a special station by the pool that makes daily specials such as freshly cooked waffles and pancakes. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The buffet dining venues have excellent Greek specialties, including a salad bar with fresh, locally sourced ingredients. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Cristal’s dessert selections include honey-drenched, flaky baklava and other homemade Greek treats. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The larger of two traditional dining venues, the 392-seat La Scala Restaurant is located on the port side of Deck 8. While there is a self-service buffet, lunch and dinner also feature a la carte menu service. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen There is a small private dining room near the entrance to the La Scala Restaurant. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Caruso Restaurant can accommodate up to 248 guests and is located on the port side of Deck 5. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen This is a port-facing view in the aft portion of the Caruso Restaurant. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Tables in both the La Scala and Caruso Restaurants are set with bottles of extra virgin olive oil and aged balsamic vinegar. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Among the most popular courses served aboard the Cristal is the delicious horiatiki or Greek villager’s salad with tomatoes, bell peppers, onions, kalamata olives and feta cheese. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Every day there are different Greek courses on the menu, including this Eggplant Imam Topped With Onion Ragout, which is drizzled in olive oil. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Two Category S1 Imperial Suites are at the top of the Cristal’s accommodation tier. Measuring 468-square-feet, they are located at the forward end of Deck 6. This is the living room and dining area of Suite 6200. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Imperial Suites have separate bedrooms with a queen-sized bed. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Imperial Suite bathrooms are especially large and feature a shower and full tub. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Forward facing Imperial Suite balconies are lined in teak and feature a dining table as well as deck chairs and a Jacuzzi tub. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Eight Category SB Balcony Suites are located on Deck 7, measuring 388-square-feet. This is the living room, which features a sofa bed and a dining nook. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen SB Balcony Suites have separate bedrooms with a queen-sized bed that can convert to two twins. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen SB Balcony Suites have small, triangular teak-lined balconies. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen All staterooms on the Cristal are stocked with shampoo and shower gel dispensers and soap bars. In suites, shampoo, gel, conditioner and moisturizer are provided. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Category XF, XE and XD Outside Staterooms are located on Decks 7, 6 and 5 and measure 161-square-feet. They feature picture windows, twin beds, a sofa bed, flat screen television, refrigerator, phone, individually controlled air conditioning, a writing desk and plenty of storage space. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Bathrooms in Category XF, XE and XD staterooms feature tiled floors and wedge-shaped shower compartments with sliding glass doors. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Category XC Outside Staterooms measure 118-square-feet, have four berths in addition to a sofa bed and feature large picture windows. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Category XB Outside Staterooms measure 108-square-feet and have two lower beds. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen This is a wheelchair-accessible Category XB Outside Stateroom with a different bedding configuration to provide extra floor space. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Wheelchair-accessible staterooms have wider doors and modified bathrooms. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Category XBO Outside Staterooms measure 108-square-feet and have up to four berths. All feature picture windows with an obstructed view. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Category XA Outside Staterooms measure 118-square feet and have portholes instead of picture windows. They can accommodate up to four guests. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Category IE Inside Staterooms measure 108-square-feet and feature two lower beds. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen Category IB Inside Staterooms measure 108-square-feet and can accommodate up to four guests. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen The Cristal is based in Aegean, Ionian and Adriatic cruise service during the summer for Celestyal Cruises. (Photo: Peter Knego) Fullscreen In the winter, the Cristal cruises to Cuba under the Cuba Cruises banner on seven night departures from Havana and Montego Bay, Jamaica. (Photo: Cuba Cruises) Fullscreen Like this topic?
